speaker: Sam
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: And I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: Have you heard this joke, Neil? Question: what’s a rat’s favourite game?

speaker: Neil
text: I don’t know, Sam, what is a rat’s favourite game?

speaker: Sam
text: Hide and squeak!

speaker: Neil
text: Ha-ha-ha! Very funny!

speaker: Sam
text: Well, I’m glad you’re laughing because, as we’ll be finding out in this programme, laughter is good for you! In fact, laughter is often called ‘the best medicine’.

speaker: Neil
text: And it seems that’s really true, medically speaking. Laughing releases anti-stress endorphins into the body and there’s evidence that people who laugh recover more quickly from illness, including Covid.

speaker: Sam
text: Laughing is an essential part of what makes us human. Babies cry straight from birth but the next sound they make, often as young as two or three months, is laughter.

speaker: Neil
text: And who can hear a baby laugh without laughing themselves? Laughter is catching.

speaker: Sam
text: But before we start tickling our funny bones, I have a quiz question for you, Neil, and it’s no laughing matter. Laughter can be a serious business. In fact, there’s a scientific field of study into laughter and its effects on the human body. But what is this study called? Is it:

speaker: Sam
text: a) gigglology?

speaker: Sam
text: b) gelotology? or

speaker: Sam
text: c) guffology?

speaker: Neil
text: Did you make those words up, Sam? They sound a bit funny to me! I’ll say the study of laughter is called b) gelotology.

speaker: Sam
text: OK, Neil, but you’ll be laughing on the other side of your face if you’re wrong! Anyway, we’ll find out the correct answer later in the programme.

speaker: Neil
text: Someone who’s an expert in the study of laughing – whatever it’s called – is cognitive neuroscientist, Professor Sophie Scott. Here she explains to David Edmonds, presenter of BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea, exactly how a laugh is produced.

speaker: rib cage
text: Laughing is a variation of breathing. Like breathing, it involves the rib cage.

speaker: rib cageprimitive
text: When you laugh you get these very, very large, very fast contractions of the rib cage. And it’s a very primitive way of making a sound, so you’re really just squeezing air out in big bouts. Each of those individual squeezes gives you a ‘ha!’ sound.

speaker: rib cage
text: The ‘ha-ha’ sound you make when you laugh comes from your rib cage - a structure made of bones, called ribs, inside your chest which protects the heart and lungs. The rib cage works like a drum to amplify a laugh.

speaker: Neil
text: It’s the reason why jokes are sometimes called ‘rib-ticklers’.

speaker: primitive
text: Professor Scott calls this a very primitive way of making sounds because it’s simple, natural and essentially human.

speaker: primitive
text: The word primitive can be used to describe anything relating to the basic way humans lived in their early stages of development, before money, machines or writing were invented.

speaker: Sam
text: Primitive human noises, like crying and laughing, link to a universal human experience, and this can be seen in the large number of words we use to talk about them. In English, ‘chuckle’, ‘giggle’, ‘chortle’, ‘cackle’ and ‘guffaw’ all describe different types of laughter.

speaker: Neil
text: Right, so how would you describe a ‘giggle’, Sam?

speaker: giggle
text: I’d say a giggle is laughing in a quiet but uncontrolled way, like a child who finds something very funny or feels embarrassed.

speaker: guffaw
text: Unlike a guffaw which is when you blast out a very loud laugh, often at something stupid or rude someone has said.

speaker: Sam
text: But humans aren’t the only animals to laugh. We belong to the same family as other primates like chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutans, all of whom laugh.

speaker: Neil
text: Even rats tickle each other and make squeaky noises like laughter when they play. Here’s Professor Scott again to take up the story for BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea.

speaker: mammalsjuveniles
text: Play is a very important behaviour for mammals – all mammals play when they’re juveniles and some mammals play their whole lives, and laughter is a sort of an invitation to play, it’s a sign that you’re playing.

speaker: mammals
text: Professor Scott says that laughter is an important social tool for all mammals – animals, including humans, dogs and whales, which give birth to live young, rather than laying eggs, and who feed their young with milk.

speaker: juveniles
text: By laughing, young mammals - sometimes called juveniles - signal that they want to play, and young rats who don’t laugh back are more likely to get a bite than a giggle. And a rat bite is nothing to laugh about.

speaker: Sam
text: What a lot of facts we’ve learned about laughter, Neil!

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, we could almost be experts on laughter… ‘Guffologists’, isn’t that what you called them, Sam?

speaker: Sam
text: Ah yes, in my quiz question I asked you to name the scientific study of laughter and its effects on the body.

speaker: Neil
text: I’m almost certain it’s not ‘gigglology’ or ‘guffology’!  So, the answer must be…

speaker: Sam
text: Gelotology! The correct answer! Well done, Neil, I knew you were good for a laugh!

speaker: rib cage
text: OK. Let’s recap the vocabulary from the programme before you think up any more terrible jokes! First, we had rib cage – the structure in your chest which is made of ribs, and produces the sound of a laugh.

speaker: primitive
text: The adjective primitive relates to the simple, natural way humans lived in their early stages of development.

speaker: giggles
text: There are different types of laughter, including giggles - childlike laughter in a quiet but uncontrolled way.

speaker: guffaw
text: And guffaw is when you laugh out loud, often at something someone has said.

speaker: Mammals
text: Mammals are animals, including humans, which give birth to live young and feed them with milk.

speaker: juvenile.
text: And finally, a young animal which is not fully grown can be called a juvenile.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, it’s been a laugh a minute, Sam, but unfortunately our six minutes are up.

speaker: Sam
text: Join us again soon for more trending topics, useful vocabulary, and, who knows, maybe some terrible jokes, here at 6 Minute English. Bye for now!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!
